title: 110_hr6633
content: The Employee Verification Amendment Act of 2008 extends programs under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 by increasing the period from 11 years to 16 years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the protection of Social Security Administration programs. The Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security will have an agreement for funding starting in 2008 to cover costs related to the responsibilities under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. This includes acquiring and maintaining necessary technological equipment and systems. The agreement between the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security will provide funds quarterly in advance for the employment verification system. An annual reconciliation of actual costs incurred will be reviewed by the Office of Inspector General of the Social Security Administration and the Department of Homeland Security. The agreement between the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security will provide funding to cover the costs of the responsibilities under section 404 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. If an agreement is not reached by October 1 of a fiscal year, the previous agreement will be deemed in effect on an interim basis, with adjustments for inflation and changes in the volume of requests under the basic pilot confirmation system. If an interim agreement applies for a fiscal year, the Commissioner and the Secretary must notify relevant committees of the failure to reach the required agreement by October 1. Updates on negotiations must be provided every 90 days until an agreement is reached. SEC. 4. GAO STUDY OF BASIC PILOT CONFIRMATION SYSTEM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations under the basic pilot confirmation system. The study will analyze the causes, processes for remedy, and effects of these errors on individuals, employers, and Federal agencies. A report is due within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations under the basic pilot confirmation system to relevant congressional committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. GAO to study effects of Basic Pilot Program on small entities. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the Committees on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives and the Senate analyzing the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities. The report will include the costs of compliance, number of small entities enrolled, and projected compliance requirements. The Comptroller General will submit a report analyzing the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities. The report will cover compliance costs, enrollment numbers, and projected requirements. It will also address factors impacting small entities' participation, steps taken to minimize economic impact, and separate direct and indirect effects. Specific details will be provided for small businesses with fewer than 50 employees. The Comptroller General will submit a report analyzing the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities, specifically small businesses with fewer than 50 employees and those operating in States mandating the program's use. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 31, 2008.
